title: Paying to See the Trevi Fountain in Rome
summary: In Rome, Italy, tourists will soon need to pay €2 to get close to the famous Trevi Fountain starting in February 2026. This fee helps the city take care of the fountain and manage the many visitors. The mayor says it will make things less crowded. People can still see the fountain for free from far away. Kids under five and some others don't have to pay. The money from the fee will go to the city, not to charity like the coins thrown in the water. This is part of a new plan for some places in Rome where locals get free entry but tourists pay.

background_read: The Trevi Fountain is a famous landmark in Rome, Italy, built in the 18th century. Many tourists visit it every day, throwing coins into the water for good luck, and those coins go to charity. Rome is a big city with lots of old monuments that need care. The city is trying new ways to handle too many visitors and keep places nice for everyone.
Article_Structure: WHO: Tourists and the mayor of Rome, Roberto Gualtieri
WHAT: A €2 fee to get close to the Trevi Fountain starting in 2026
WHERE: Rome, Italy, at the Trevi Fountain
WHY: To help the city with upkeep and reduce crowds

perspectives.description: The fee is a good idea to manage tourists and raise money for maintenance.
Some tourists might not like paying extra, but it could make visits less crowded.
